0: A fundus photo showing a healthy retina with no diabetic retinopathy lesions.
Normal retinal image with clear vasculature and no microaneurysms or hemorrhages.
Healthy fundus scan without red hemorrhage or yellow hard exudates.
No signs of diabetic eye disease in this retinal photograph.
Clean optic disc and macula with no DR-related changes.
1: Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy with a few microaneurysms.
Fundus image showing small red dots (microaneurysms) with minimal changes.
Early DR: scattered microaneurysms and tiny red hemorrhages.
Retinal photo with subtle red lesions but no major exudates.
Mild DR appearance with only limited retinal abnormalities.
2: Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy with multiple lesions.
Retinal image showing microaneurysms, red hemorrhage, and yellow hard exudates.
Moderate DR with scattered hemorrhages and visible exudates.
Fundus scan with more frequent red dots and hard exudate deposits.
Moderate stage DR with notable retinal lesion burden.
3: Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy with extensive hemorrhages.
Fundus photo showing widespread red hemorrhages and dense lesion clusters.
Severe DR with numerous microaneurysms and hard exudates.
Retinal scan demonstrating advanced nonproliferative changes.
Heavy lesion load consistent with severe nonproliferative disease.
4: Fundus image showing abnormal new vessel growth and severe DR changes.
Advanced DR with neovascularization and risk of vitreous hemorrhage.
Proliferative stage with fibrous proliferation and active neovessels.
Severe diabetic eye disease requiring urgent treatment.

0: Fingerprint pattern of type Stone (WrI or Incomplete Peacock). Visual pattern looks like an incomplete peacock feather.
Incomplete Peacock Whorl (WrI): Has 1 inner delta and 1 outer delta, but the inner delta may be incomplete.
Fingerprint with peacock-like pattern but incomplete inner features (Stone type).
Dermatoglyphics: Stone pattern (WrI), resembling a peacock feather that hasn't fully formed.
1: Fingerprint pattern of type Gold (Wt or Concentric Whorl). Visual pattern looks like a target or bullseye.
Concentric Whorl (Wt): Central ridges form complete concentric circles around the center.
Gold type fingerprint: Within the innermost 3 circles, there is at least one complete closed and independent loop.
Dermatoglyphics: Whorl pattern with concentric circular ridges forming a target shape.
2: Fingerprint pattern of type Dream (Lf or Falling Loop). Visual pattern is a U-shape flowing out with convergence at the top.
Falling Loop (Lf): Has 1 outer delta and a convergence point at the top of the U-shape.
Dream type fingerprint: At the top of the U-shape, 4 or more ridges converge forming an acute angle and do not flow out.
Dermatoglyphics: Falling Loop pattern with ridges forming a sharp wedge at the top.
3: Fingerprint pattern of type Electricity (Wc or Composite Whorl). Visual pattern looks like a Tai-Chi shape.
Composite Whorl (Wc): Central ridges form a complete S-line.
Electricity type fingerprint: S-line structure with ridges on both sides flowing INTO deltas.
Dermatoglyphics: Composite/Tai-Chi pattern with an S-shaped core and two deltas.
4: Fingerprint pattern of type Wind (At or Tented Arch). Visual pattern has ridges rising high with a tent-like peak.
Tented Arch (At): Ridges rise sharply in the center forming a tent-like peak.
Wind type fingerprint: High arch with a sharp peak in the center.
Dermatoglyphics: Arch pattern with a significant spike or tent-like feature in the middle.
5: Fingerprint pattern of type Electricity with Wind (Composite of Tai-Chi and Tented Arch).
Fingerprint showing features of both Electricity (Composite Whorl) and Wind (Tented Arch) patterns.
Combined pattern: Tai-Chi S-line structure mixed with a sharp tented arch peak.
6: Fingerprint pattern of type Drill (Wd or Double Loop Whorl). Visual pattern looks like a flattened Tai-Chi shape.
Double Loop Whorl (Wd): Central ridges form a complete S-line where ridges flow OUT OF deltas.
Drill type fingerprint: S-line structure distinguishing it from Composite Whorl by ridge flow direction.
Dermatoglyphics: Two distinct loop formations twisting together like a drill.
7: Fingerprint pattern of type Light (We or Press Whorl). Visual pattern looks like a football or olive shape.
Press Whorl (We): Central ridges form an elongated spiral.
Light type fingerprint: Within the central 3 circles, the length is at least 2.5 times the width.
Dermatoglyphics: Elongated whorl pattern resembling a pressed circle or olive.
8: Fingerprint pattern of type Water (Lu or Ulnar Loop). Visual pattern looks like a horseshoe flowing towards the little finger.
Ulnar Loop (Lu): Ridges form a U-shape opening towards the little finger side with 1 outer delta.
Water type fingerprint: Classic loop pattern flowing in the ulnar direction.
Dermatoglyphics: Ulnar Loop, the most common fingerprint pattern.
9: Fingerprint pattern of type Fire (Lr or Radial Loop). Visual pattern looks like a horseshoe flowing towards the thumb.
Radial Loop (Lr): Ridges form a U-shape opening towards the thumb side with 1 outer delta.
Fire type fingerprint: Loop pattern flowing in the radial (thumb) direction.
Dermatoglyphics: Radial Loop, less common than Ulnar Loop.
10: Fingerprint pattern of type Wood (Ws or Spiral Whorl). Visual pattern looks like a spiral.
Spiral Whorl (Ws): Central ridges form a spiral pattern around the center.
Wood type fingerprint: Within the central 3 circles, the length is less than 2 times the width.
Dermatoglyphics: Whorl pattern with ridges spiraling out from the core.
11: Fingerprint pattern of type Earth (As or Simple Arch). Visual pattern looks like a flat mound or bow.
Simple Arch (As): Smooth arched ridges flowing from one side to the other without deltas.
Earth type fingerprint: Simple, flat arch with no complexity or sharp peaks.
Dermatoglyphics: The simplest arch pattern with gentle waves.
12: Fingerprint pattern of type Ground (Aul or Ulnar Loop Arch). Visual pattern looks like a horseshoe but with 0 deltas.
Ulnar Loop Arch (Aul): Overall ridges vary form a U-shape towards the little finger but lack a delta.
Ground type fingerprint: Resembles Ulnar Loop but is technically an Arch due to missing delta.
Dermatoglyphics: Hybrid arch-loop pattern classified as Arch.
13: Fingerprint pattern of type Mountain (Ae or Elevated Arch). Visual pattern looks like a raised hill.
Elevated Arch (Ae): Bottom ridges form an arc enclosing a triangular or circular shape.
Mountain type fingerprint: Arch with a prominent raised area or enclosed block at the base.
Dermatoglyphics: Complex arch pattern with elevations.
14: Fingerprint pattern of type Rock (Wp or Peacock Whorl). Visual pattern looks like a peacock feather.
Peacock Whorl (Wp): Has 1 inner delta and 1 outer delta with symmetrical ridge convergence.
Rock type fingerprint: Ridges on both sides converge symmetrically or cross each other.
Dermatoglyphics: Distinctive peacock eye pattern with two deltas.
15: Fingerprint pattern of type Fire Light (Composite of Radial Loop and Press Whorl).
Fingerprint showing combined features of Fire (Radial Loop) and Light (Press Whorl) patterns.
Combined pattern: Radial flow mixed with an elongated, olive-shaped whorl.
16: Fingerprint pattern of type Fire Wood (Composite of Radial Loop and Spiral Whorl).
Fingerprint showing combined features of Fire (Radial Loop) and Wood (Spiral Whorl) patterns.
Combined pattern: Radial flow mixed with a spiral whorl.
17: Fingerprint pattern of type Fire Earth (Composite of Radial Loop and Simple Arch).
Fingerprint showing combined features of Fire (Radial Loop) and Earth (Simple Arch) patterns.
Combined pattern: Radial flow mixed with simple arched ridges.
18: Fingerprint pattern of type Fire Drill (Composite of Radial Loop and Double Loop Whorl).
Fingerprint showing combined features of Fire (Radial Loop) and Drill (Double Loop) patterns.
Combined pattern: Radial flow mixed with twisted double loop structures.

0: Normal mammogram with no masses or calcifications.
Healthy breast X-ray showing normal tissue pattern.
Mammography scan without suspicious lesions or distortions.
No breast mass or calcification visible in this mammogram.
Clear mammogram with normal breast parenchyma.
1: Mammogram showing calcifications in breast tissue.
Mammography scan with microcalcifications visible.
Breast X-ray displaying calcified deposits.
Clustered calcification pattern on mammography.
Calcifications present without a discrete mass.
2: Mammogram showing a circumscribed mass with well-defined borders.
Breast X-ray with a smooth, round or oval mass.
Circumscribed breast lesion visible on mammography.
Well-defined mass in breast tissue on the scan.
3: Mammogram showing a spiculated mass with irregular borders.
Breast X-ray with star-shaped or spiculated lesion.
Spiculated tumor mass on mammography suggestive of malignancy.
Irregular spiculated breast lesion visible in the scan.
4: Mammogram showing ill-defined mass or miscellaneous abnormality.
Breast X-ray with non-specific dense region or ill-defined lesion.
Mammography image with unclassified abnormal features.
Ill-defined breast mass without clear margins.
Miscellaneous abnormality on mammogram requiring review.
5: Mammogram showing architectural distortion of breast tissue.
Mammography scan with distorted tissue architecture.
Breast X-ray displaying spiculated architectural changes.
Architectural distortion pattern visible on the scan.
Distorted breast parenchyma without a clear mass.
6: Mammogram showing breast asymmetry between left and right.
Mammography scan with asymmetric breast tissue density.
Noticeable asymmetry in breast tissue on the scan.

0: OCTA image showing age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
OCTA scan with macular degeneration changes and drusen.
AMD pattern with abnormal macular structure on OCTA.
Macular degeneration visible in retinal vasculature scan.
OCTA showing AMD-related vascular alterations.
1: OCTA image showing choroidal neovascularization (CNV).
Tangled bright vessels consistent with CNV on OCTA.
Subretinal neovascular membrane visible on OCTA.
CNV pattern with abnormal bright vessel network.
OCTA showing neovascular growth beneath the retina.
2: OCTA image showing central serous chorioretinopathy (CSC).
CSC features with subretinal fluid changes on OCTA.
OCTA scan showing pigment epithelial detachment.
Central serous chorioretinopathy pattern on OCTA.
CSC-related vascular and fluid changes in the scan.
3: Non-perfusion zones and microvascular changes on OCTA.
DR pattern with capillary dropout on OCTA.
OCTA scan displaying diabetic macular changes.
Diabetic retinopathy features visible in vascular scan.
4: OCTA image showing normal retinal vasculature.
Healthy OCTA scan with normal foveal avascular zone.
Normal retinal blood flow pattern on OCTA.
Clear, normal vasculature in the OCTA image.
5: OCTA image showing other retinal abnormalities.
Non-specific retinal vascular changes on OCTA.
Other retinal disease pattern visible in the scan.
Abnormal OCTA findings not in major categories.
6: OCTA image showing retinal vein occlusion (RVO).
Venous occlusion pattern with congestion on OCTA.
OCTA scan displaying retinal venous blockage.
RVO features with non-perfusion and vessel changes.
Retinal vein occlusion visible in the vascular scan.

0: Histopathology image of normal oral mucosa tissue.
Microscopic view of healthy oral epithelium.
Normal oral tissue biopsy without malignancy.
Healthy oral cavity tissue under microscope.
Non-cancerous oral mucosa histology slide.
1: Histopathology image of oral squamous cell carcinoma.
Microscopic view of malignant oral cancer tissue.
Oral carcinoma biopsy showing atypical cells and lesions.
Oral cancer tissue with ulcer or tumor region visible.
Malignant oral squamous cell carcinoma histology slide.
